_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Klamath Cogeneration Project

1.  Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies:

We at the Klamath Cogeneration Project are committed to employee, public and environmental safety.  This commitment is demonstrated by our comprehensive accidental release prevention program that covers areas such as the design, installation, operating procedures, maintenance, and employee training associated with the processes at our facility.  It is our policy to implement appropriate controls to prevent possible releases of regulated substances.  If such a release were to occur, our highly trained employees are on hand to control and mitigate the effects of the release.  We are also completely coordinated with the Klamath County Fire District No. 1 who provides our emergency response services.

2.  The Stationary Source and the Regulated Substances Handled:

We have one regulated substance present at our facility.  This substance is Ammonia (anhydrous).  The maximum inventory of Ammonia (anhydrous) that is expected to be present in this facility, based on process/operational requirements, is 102,928 pounds.

3.  The General Accidental Release Prevention Program and the Chemical Specific Prevention Steps:

Our facility has taken the following steps as required by 40 CFR Part 68 of the EPA.  Our Ammonia (anhydrous) process is subject to the OSHA PSM Standard (29 CFR 1910.119), and the EPCRA 302 reporting requirements.  The following sections briefly describe the elements of the release prevention program that is in place at our facility.

Process Safety Information:

Our facility conducts comprehensive studies to ensure that hazards associated with our process are identified and controlled efficiently.  The methodology used to carry out these analyses is the Checklist.  The studies are undertaken by a team of qualified personnel with expertise in engineering and process operations and are revalidated at a regular interval of every three years.  Any findings related to

the hazard analyses are addressed in a timely manner.

Operating Procedures:

The Klamath Cogeneration Project maintains written operating procedures.  These procedures address various modes of operation such as initial start-up, normal operations, temporary operations, emergency shutdown, emergency operations, normal shutdown, and start-up after a turnaround.  The information is regularly reviewed and is readily accessible to operators involved in the process.

Training:

The Klamath Cogeneration Project has a comprehensive training program in place to ensure that employees who are operating processes are competent in the operating procedures associated with those processes.  New employees receive basic classroom training in process operations, followed by on-the-job supervision until they are deemed competent to work independently.  Refresher training is provided at least annually and more frequently as needed.

Mechanical Integrity:

The Klamath Cogeneration Project carries out highly documented maintenance checks on process equipment to ensure proper operation.  Process equipment examined by those checks includes pressure vessels, storage tanks, piping systems, relief and vent systems, emergency shutdown systems, controls and pumps.  Qualified personnel complete maintenance operations with special training in maintenance practices.  Furthermore, these personnel are given specialized training as needed to ensure their competency.  Any equipment deficiencies identified by the maintenance checks are corrected in a timely manner.

Management of Change:

Written procedures are in place at the Klamath Cogeneration Project to manage change in process chemicals, technology, equipment and processes.  Process operators, maintenance personnel, or any other employees whose job tasks are affected by a modification of process operations, are promptly informed of, and given, training to deal with the modifications.

Pre-Startup Reviews:

Pre-startup reviews related to new proc

esses, and to modifications of established processes, are conducted to confirm that the construction, equipment, and operating and maintenance procedures are suitable for a safe start-up prior to placing the equipment in service.

Compliance Audits:

The Klamath Cogeneration Project conducts audits on a regular basis to determine whether the provisions set forth by the RMP Regulation are being implemented.  These audits are completed at least every three years and any corrective actions identified during the audits are completed in a timely manner.

Incident Investigation:

The Klamath Cogeneration Project promptly investigates any incident that has resulted in, or had the potential to result in a catastrophic release of a regulated substance.  These investigations are conducted to determine the cause of the  incident, as well as any corrective actions to prevent the release from recurring.  All incident investigation reports are retained for a minimum of 5 years.

Employee Participation:

The Klamath Cogeneration Project believes that process safety management and incident investigation are a team effort.  Company employees are encouraged to express their views concerning incident prevention issues and to recommend improvements.  In addition, our employees have access to all information created as part of our implementation of the RMP Regulation, including information resulting from process hazard analyses, in particular.

Contractors:

The Klamath Cogeneration Project hires contractors to conduct specialized maintenance and construction activities.  Prior to selecting a contractor, a thorough evaluation of the contractor's safety performance is completed.  The Klamath Cogeneration Project has a strict policy of informing contractors of known potential hazards related to the contractor's work on, or adjacent to, our process.  Contractors are also informed of all the procedures for emergency notification and evacuation, should an accidental release of a regulated su

bstance occur.

4.  5-Year Accident History:

The Klamath Cogeneration Project has never had an accidental release of Ammonia (anhydrous) at their facility.

5.  Emergency Response Plan:

The Klamath Cogeneration Project is included in the written community emergency response plan.  This facility also has an emergency response plan.  The emergency response plan includes specific actions to be taken in response to accidental releases of regulated substances.  The emergency response plan includes procedures for informing the public and local response agencies of a chemical release.  The emergency response plan includes information on emergency health care.  

The date of the most recent review/update of the emergency response plan was February 20, 2004 

The date of the most recent emergency response training for our employees was February 19, 2004.  

The local agency that is coordinating the facility emergency response plan is Klamath County Fire District No. 1.

6.  Planned Changes to Improve Safety:

The Klamath Cogeneration Project will continue to revise their policies, procedures, plans and training as soon as possible after any changes are deemed necessary.  The retraining of employees and non-employees (if required) will occur as soon as possible after these documents are revised.  Preplanning visits and training will be conducted with the Klamath County Fire District No. 1 on at least an annual basis, and more frequently if dictated by any changes in our emergency response system.  We will conduct emergency notification, evacuation and employee accountability drills at our facility at least on an annual basis.
